elements.content: A metal–organic compound [Cd­(quin)2(4-nvp)2] [1; Hquin = quinoline-2-carboxylic acid and 4-nvp = 4-(1-naphthylvinyl)­pyridine] undergoes topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition by sunlight irradiation to generate a one-dimensional coordination polymer. This reaction is thermally reversible, and switching between two crystalline forms can be monitored by conductivity measurements.
elements.clean_text: A metal-organic compound [Cd(quin)2(4-nvp)2] [1; Hquin = quinoline-2-carboxylic acid and 4-nvp = 4-(1-naphthylvinyl)pyridine] undergoes topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition by sunlight irradiation to generate a one-dimensional coordination polymer. This reaction is thermally reversible, and switching between two crystalline forms can be monitored by conductivity measurements.

elements.content:
A metal−organic compound undergoes a [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction by sunlight irradiation to form a one-dimensional polymeric chain accompanied by switching of the electrical conductivity.

In recent years, solid-state reactions involving structural transformations receive considerable attention among the researchers working in the field of coordination polymers (CPs). This is attributed to the involvement of a solvent-free simple synthetic procedure and the formation of product that may otherwise be difficult to obtain by a conventional route. Of the various solid-state reactions, photochemical [2 + 2] photodimerization, by which a stereoseletive cyclobutane ring is formed in photoactive organic as well as coordination compounds, is particularly interesting. More recently, reversible [2 + 2] photodimerization involving the formation and cleavage of a cyclobutane ring has currently emerged as a new synthetic route for the fabrication of molecular switching, optical recording and storage devices, sensors, and photochemical actuators. However, reversible photodimerization reactions accompanied by switching of the conductivity for the fabrication of electronic and optoelectronic devices are still scarce.
elements.clean_text:
A metal-organic compound undergoes a [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction by sunlight irradiation to form a one-dimensional polymeric chain accompanied by switching of the electrical conductivity.

In recent years, solid-state reactions involving structural transformations receive considerable attention among the researchers working in the field of coordination polymers (CPs). This is attributed to the involvement of a solvent-free simple synthetic procedure and the formation of product that may otherwise be difficult to obtain by a conventional route. Of the various solid-state reactions, photochemical [2 + 2] photodimerization, by which a stereoseletive cyclobutane ring is formed in photoactive organic as well as coordination compounds, is particularly interesting. More recently, reversible [2 + 2] photodimerization involving the formation and cleavage of a cyclobutane ring has currently emerged as a new synthetic route for the fabrication of molecular switching, optical recording and storage devices, sensors, and photochemical actuators. However, reversible photodimerization reactions accompanied by switching of the conductivity for the fabrication of electronic and optoelectronic devices are still scarce.

elements.content: Most of the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions have been carried out using harmful UV radiation. On the basis of green synthesis, dimerization reactions using solar radiation have rarely been explored. Herein, we report the synthesis of a monomeric metal–organic compound, [Cd­(quin)2(4-nvp)2] [1; Hquin = quinoline-2-carboxylic acid and 4-nvp = 4-(1-naphthylvinyl)­pyridine; CCDC 1868133], which undergoes sunlight-induced topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition and generates a one-dimensional (1D) CP via crystal-to-crystal transformation. However, the structure of the dimerized product [Cd­(quin)2(rctt-4-pncb)] n [1′; rctt-4-pncb = 1,3-bis­(4′-pyridyl)-2,4-bis­(naphthyl)­cyclobutane; CCDC 1868134] has been confirmed by a single-crystal X-ray crystallographic experiment of the crystal obtained by keeping the reactor in sunlight. Because of this structural change, there has been a significant effect on the electrical property of the material. The conductivity becomes notably low after dimerization. Interestingly, a cyclobutane ring in a 1D chain could be cleaved back to form olefin by heating. This reversible reaction accompanied by switching of the conductivity leads to the development of an electronic device based on molecular switches.
elements.clean_text: Most of the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions have been carried out using harmful UV radiation. On the basis of green synthesis, dimerization reactions using solar radiation have rarely been explored. Herein, we report the synthesis of a monomeric metal-organic compound, [Cd(quin)2(4-nvp)2] [1; Hquin = quinoline-2-carboxylic acid and 4-nvp = 4-(1-naphthylvinyl)pyridine; CCDC 1868133], which undergoes sunlight-induced topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition and generates a one-dimensional (1D) CP via crystal-to-crystal transformation. However, the structure of the dimerized product [Cd(quin)2(rctt-4-pncb)] n  [1'; rctt-4-pncb = 1,3-bis(4'-pyridyl)-2,4-bis(naphthyl)cyclobutane; CCDC 1868134] has been confirmed by a single-crystal X-ray crystallographic experiment of the crystal obtained by keeping the reactor in sunlight. Because of this structural change, there has been a significant effect on the electrical property of the material. The conductivity becomes notably low after dimerization. Interestingly, a cyclobutane ring in a 1D chain could be cleaved back to form olefin by heating. This reversible reaction accompanied by switching of the conductivity leads to the development of an electronic device based on molecular switches.

elements.content: Compound 1 has been synthesized in the dark by the slow diffusion of 4-nvp in methanol and Hquin in ethanol into an aqueous solution of Cd­(NO3)2·6H2O and triethylamine in water/methanol. However, compound 1′ can be synthesized by either exposing the reaction mixture to sunlight or keeping the crystals of 1 (obtained in the dark) in strong sunlight. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P1̅ with Z = 1. Each cadmium­(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, ligated to two chelating quin ligands in the equatorial plane and two 4-nvp ligands at the axial sites (). In the solid-state structure, a pair of 4-nvp ligands from two adjacent moieties produces a head-to-tail arrangement with a distance between the centers of two CC bonds of 4.094 Å (), which is highly favorable for dimerization according to Schmidt’s criteria (<4.2 Å). Compound 1 further undergoes extensive π···π-stacking interactions among the aromatic rings of the quin ligands, with the centroid–centroid distances in the range of 3.843–3.848 Å, to fabricate a two-dimensional supramolecular layer structure (Figure S1). Here, the presence of π···π interactions facilitates higher charge transport.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 has been synthesized in the dark by the slow diffusion of 4-nvp in methanol and Hquin in ethanol into an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O and triethylamine in water/methanol. However, compound 1' can be synthesized by either exposing the reaction mixture to sunlight or keeping the crystals of 1 (obtained in the dark) in strong sunlight. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P1̅ with Z = 1. Each cadmium(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, ligated to two chelating quin ligands in the equatorial plane and two 4-nvp ligands at the axial sites (). In the solid-state structure, a pair of 4-nvp ligands from two adjacent moieties produces a head-to-tail arrangement with a distance between the centers of two CC bonds of 4.094 Å (), which is highly favorable for dimerization according to Schmidt's criteria (<4.2 Å). Compound 1 further undergoes extensive π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interactions among the aromatic rings of the quin ligands, with the centroid-centroid distances in the range of 3.843-3.848 Å, to fabricate a two-dimensional supramolecular layer structure (Figure S1). Here, the presence of π⋅⋅⋅π interactions facilitates higher charge transport.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of compound 1 showing the alignment of 4-nvp ligands. Hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  X-ray crystal structure of compound 1 showing the alignment of 4-nvp ligands. Hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity.

elements.content: During exposure of the reaction mixture to sunlight, compound 1′ is directly obtained, as is evident from the appearance of the characteristic sharp single peak of a cyclobutane proton at δ 5.19 in the 1H NMR spectrum in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6. Here, 100% dimerized product 1′ has been achieved. Single-crystal X-ray structure determination of 1′ exhibits quantitative dimerization along with topochemical structural transformation from a monomeric coordination compound to a 1D polymeric chain (). However, the solid-state structure of 1′ reveals the disappearance of π···π-stacking arrangements because of the formation of a strained cyclobutane ring.
elements.clean_text: During exposure of the reaction mixture to sunlight, compound 1' is directly obtained, as is evident from the appearance of the characteristic sharp single peak of a cyclobutane proton at δ 5.19 in the 1H NMR spectrum in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6. Here, 100% dimerized product 1' has been achieved. Single-crystal X-ray structure determination of 1' exhibits quantitative dimerization along with topochemical structural transformation from a monomeric coordination compound to a 1D polymeric chain (). However, the solid-state structure of 1' reveals the disappearance of π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking arrangements because of the formation of a strained cyclobutane ring.

elements.content: View showing a portion of the 1D polymeric chain of 1′. Hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  View showing a portion of the 1D polymeric chain of 1'. Hydrogen atoms are not shown for clarity.

elements.content: Interestingly, when the single crystals of compound 1 are exposed to sunlight for 2 h, they undergo dimerization to form 1′, as is obvious from 1H NMR. The structure of the dimerized product produced by sunlight irradiation could not be obtained because the single crystal shows cracking and poor X-ray-intensity data. However, in this structural transformation, the crystals still maintain their crystallinity, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. The PXRD patterns of the sunlight-irradiated product are in good agreement with those of the in situ synthesized dimerized product (Supporting Information). Therefore, it can be inferred that dimerization occurs in a green process using sunlight irradiation via crystal-to-crystal conversion.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, when the single crystals of compound 1 are exposed to sunlight for 2 h, they undergo dimerization to form 1', as is obvious from 1H NMR. The structure of the dimerized product produced by sunlight irradiation could not be obtained because the single crystal shows cracking and poor X-ray-intensity data. However, in this structural transformation, the crystals still maintain their crystallinity, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. The PXRD patterns of the sunlight-irradiated product are in good agreement with those of the in situ synthesized dimerized product (Supporting Information). Therefore, it can be inferred that dimerization occurs in a green process using sunlight irradiation via crystal-to-crystal conversion.

elements.content: Most importantly, compound 1′ reverts back to 1 during heating of the crystals at 200 °C for 6 h, as is evident from the complete disappearance of cyclobutane protons and the emergence of olefinic protons in the 1H NMR spectrum in DMSO-d 6. The reversion has also been confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns of heated 1′ and the original compound 1 obtained in the dark (Supporting Information). This reversible structural transformation between two compounds prompted us to check switching of the conductivity of the materials.
elements.clean_text: Most importantly, compound 1' reverts back to 1 during heating of the crystals at 200 °C for 6 h, as is evident from the complete disappearance of cyclobutane protons and the emergence of olefinic protons in the 1H NMR spectrum in DMSO-d 6. The reversion has also been confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns of heated 1' and the original compound 1 obtained in the dark (Supporting Information). This reversible structural transformation between two compounds prompted us to check switching of the conductivity of the materials.

elements.content: In order to examine the conducting nature of the materials, the direct optical band gaps (E g) of 1 and 1′ have been estimated as 3.33 and 4.08 eV, respectively, using Tauc’s plot (Figure S3). The obtained band-gap values indicate the semiconducting nature of the materials. These data are well consistent with the band-gap (highest occupied molecular orbital–lowest unoccupied molecular orbital gap) values obtained from density functional theory calculations (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: In order to examine the conducting nature of the materials, the direct optical band gaps (E g) of 1 and 1' have been estimated as 3.33 and 4.08 eV, respectively, using Tauc's plot (Figure S3). The obtained band-gap values indicate the semiconducting nature of the materials. These data are well consistent with the band-gap (highest occupied molecular orbital-lowest unoccupied molecular orbital gap) values obtained from density functional theory calculations (Figure S4).

elements.content: To further analyze the intrinsic electrical properties of the compounds, metal (Al)–semiconductor (MS; compound 1/1′) junction thin-film devices have been fabricated by the indium–tin oxide (ITO)/compound 1/1′/Al sandwich structure. With the ITO/compound 1 or 1′ ohmic contact, the representative I–V characteristics of the Al/compound 1/1′ have been obtained (). The conductivities of 1 and 1′ have been evaluated as 7.36 × 10–5 and 8.84 × 10–6 S m–1, respectively, which depicts approximately ∼9 times better conductivity of compound 1. Both characteristic curves indicate a rectifying nature with I on/I off values 63.83 and 25.58 for 1 and 1′, respectively, at the applied bias potential ±2 V, signifying Schottky barrier diode (SBD) behavior of the materials. The electrical conductivity is specific to a particular material and varies with the different packing arrangements of the solids. The three-dimensional structure consisting of aligned chain polymers exhibits semiconducting behavior. Thus, compound 1 with π···π-stacking interactions shows better conductivity.
elements.clean_text: To further analyze the intrinsic electrical properties of the compounds, metal (Al)-semiconductor (MS; compound 1/1') junction thin-film devices have been fabricated by the indium-tin oxide (ITO)/compound 1/1'/Al sandwich structure. With the ITO/compound 1 or 1' ohmic contact, the representative I-V characteristics of the Al/compound 1/1' have been obtained (). The conductivities of 1 and 1' have been evaluated as 7.36 × 10-5 and 8.84 × 10-6 S m-1, respectively, which depicts approximately ~9 times better conductivity of compound 1. Both characteristic curves indicate a rectifying nature with I on/I off values 63.83 and 25.58 for 1 and 1', respectively, at the applied bias potential ±2 V, signifying Schottky barrier diode (SBD) behavior of the materials. The electrical conductivity is specific to a particular material and varies with the different packing arrangements of the solids. The three-dimensional structure consisting of aligned chain polymers exhibits semiconducting behavior. Thus, compound 1 with π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interactions shows better conductivity.

elements.content: I–V characteristics of compounds 1 and 1′.

In order to analyze the I–V characteristics of 1- and 1′-based SBDs in detail, thermionic emission theory has been adopted using Cheung’s method. In this regard, the ideality factor (η), potential height (ϕB), and series resistance (R S) of 1 and 1′ have been calculated. The ideality factors of compounds 1 and 1′ have been measured as 1.51 and 2.55, respectively, which depict that the MS junctions are not perfectly ideal. However, compound 1 approaches more toward ideality because the value of η is closer to 1. Here, the deviation from ideality is attributed to the inhomogeneities of the barrier height, the presence of interface states, and the junction series resistance. The barrier height has been calculated as 0.31 and 0.39 eV for 1- and 1′-based devices, respectively. The lower barrier height of the 1-based device represents the better formation of a MS junction. ϕB, η, and R S of 1- and 1′-based SBDs are listed in Table S4. All of the measured parameters show an improved performance of the 1-based device.
elements.clean_text: In order to analyze the I-V characteristics of 1- and 1'-based SBDs in detail, thermionic emission theory has been adopted using Cheung's method. In this regard, the ideality factor (η), potential height (ϕB), and series resistance (R S) of 1 and 1' have been calculated. The ideality factors of compounds 1 and 1' have been measured as 1.51 and 2.55, respectively, which depict that the MS junctions are not perfectly ideal. However, compound 1 approaches more toward ideality because the value of η is closer to 1. Here, the deviation from ideality is attributed to the inhomogeneities of the barrier height, the presence of interface states, and the junction series resistance. The barrier height has been calculated as 0.31 and 0.39 eV for 1- and 1'-based devices, respectively. The lower barrier height of the 1-based device represents the better formation of a MS junction. ϕB, η, and R S of 1- and 1'-based SBDs are listed in Table S4. All of the measured parameters show an improved performance of the 1-based device.

elements.content: To get better insight into the charge-transport property, the I–V curves of 1- and 1′-based devices have been plotted in the logarithmic scale (a). The log I versus log V curve reveals the presence of two distinct slopes with different values assigned as regions I and II. Region I refers to the ohmic regime, where the slope is ∼1 and the current follows the relationship I ∝ V. On the other hand, region II defines the characteristic trap-free space-charge-limited-current (SCLC) regime, where the slope is ∼2 and the current follows the relationship I ∝ V 2. The effective carrier mobility (μeff) has been estimated at the higher voltage region of the I versus V 2 plot by SCLC theory using by the Mott–Gurney law (b). The obtained mobility values are 7.01 × 10–10 and 4.04 × 10–11 m2 V–1 s–1 for 1 and 1′, respectively. The higher mobility of the 1-based device implies a higher transport rate. We have also estimated some key parameters such as the transit time (τ), diffusion coefficient (D), and diffusion length (L D) of the charge carrier of the materials. The estimated parameters in the SCLC region have been depicted in Table S5. From the obtained values, it can be clearly stated that the charge-transport properties of compound 1 is better than those of compound 1′. It should be mentioned that the presence of π···π interactions among the aromatic rings of the quin ligands in compound 1 results an increase in charge transport and, consequently, enhanced conductivity. On the other hand, because of the disappearance of π···π-stacking interactions in 1′, the charge-carrier mobility significantly decreases. These results are well consisent with our previously published work, in which charge transport enhances with an increase in the extent of π···π interactions on the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition.
elements.clean_text: To get better insight into the charge-transport property, the I-V curves of 1- and 1'-based devices have been plotted in the logarithmic scale (a). The log I versus log V curve reveals the presence of two distinct slopes with different values assigned as regions I and II. Region I refers to the ohmic regime, where the slope is ~1 and the current follows the relationship I ∝ V. On the other hand, region II defines the characteristic trap-free space-charge-limited-current (SCLC) regime, where the slope is ~2 and the current follows the relationship I ∝ V 2. The effective carrier mobility (μeff) has been estimated at the higher voltage region of the I versus V 2 plot by SCLC theory using by the Mott-Gurney law (b). The obtained mobility values are 7.01 × 10-10 and 4.04 × 10-11 m2 V-1 s-1 for 1 and 1', respectively. The higher mobility of the 1-based device implies a higher transport rate. We have also estimated some key parameters such as the transit time (τ), diffusion coefficient (D), and diffusion length (L D) of the charge carrier of the materials. The estimated parameters in the SCLC region have been depicted in Table S5. From the obtained values, it can be clearly stated that the charge-transport properties of compound 1 is better than those of compound 1'. It should be mentioned that the presence of π⋅⋅⋅π interactions among the aromatic rings of the quin ligands in compound 1 results an increase in charge transport and, consequently, enhanced conductivity. On the other hand, because of the disappearance of π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interactions in 1', the charge-carrier mobility significantly decreases. These results are well consisent with our previously published work, in which charge transport enhances with an increase in the extent of π⋅⋅⋅π interactions on the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition.

elements.content: In summary, a mononuclear cadmium­(II) compound and its dimerized product obtained in sunlight irradiation have been reoprted. The monomer undergoes [2 + 2] cycloaddition to form dimer in sunlight via crystal-to-crystal transformation, and the dimer can be reverted back with heating. Here, we have been able to obtain the dimerized product in a green process by avoiding ecologically harmful UV irradiation. Interestingly, this structural transformation is accompanied by switching of the conductivtiy between the monomer and dimer, which might lead to the development of electronic switching devices. More work is in progress for the fabrication of potential optoelectronic switching devices.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a mononuclear cadmium(II) compound and its dimerized product obtained in sunlight irradiation have been reoprted. The monomer undergoes [2 + 2] cycloaddition to form dimer in sunlight via crystal-to-crystal transformation, and the dimer can be reverted back with heating. Here, we have been able to obtain the dimerized product in a green process by avoiding ecologically harmful UV irradiation. Interestingly, this structural transformation is accompanied by switching of the conductivtiy between the monomer and dimer, which might lead to the development of electronic switching devices. More work is in progress for the fabrication of potential optoelectronic switching devices.

metadata.title:
Sunlight-Induced Topochemical Photodimerization and
Switching of the Conductivity of a Metal–Organic Compound
